If your database isn't included as a template you can install one manually using the JBoss EAP Command Line Interface (CLI), or by modifying the XML configuration.
Please, take special notice to the following definitions,
 * <pool> (for Datasources)
 * <xa-pool> (for XA Datasources)
 * <security>
 * <validation>
as they provide important configuration.
You can find examples for major databases in the ${platform.name} documentation, which can serve as a template for your definition.
Datasource description - Datasource Configuration Guide
List of supported databases - Supported Databases List

A Maven repository is available that allows you to build the quickstarts using the same artifacts that were used to build JBoss Data Virtualization. You can choose to have the repository added to your Maven settings.xml at this time. The Maven settings.xml will be validated against the public schema.

Unable to configure the Maven settings due to an invalid %s file. Choose Cancel to verify the file and install later. Choose Continue to proceed without configuring Maven.

The EAP admin user will be added to the host container's ManagementRealm. It can be used to access the management console and the management CLI, as well as other applications secured with the ManagementRealm.

There are several additional options for configuring Red Hat JBoss Enterprise Application Platform now that the server has been installed. Each option can be individually chosen, and will be configured in the order displayed upon pressing next. Would you like to do this now?
Configure the logging levels for Red Hat JBoss Enterprise Application Platform?
press 1 to continue, 2 to quit, 3 to redisplay.

Configure the database logging database below.

Red Hat JBoss Data Virtualization is a lean, virtual data integration solution that unlocks trapped data and delivers it as easily consumable, unified, and actionable information. JBoss Data Virtualization makes data spread across physically diverse systems-such as multiple databases, XML files, and Hadoop systems-appear as a set of tables in a local database.
Red Hat JBoss Enterprise Application Platform
Application platform that will host Red Hat JBoss Data Virtualization capabilities. Contains version ${version.major}.${version.minor}.

Add a JMS Queue by providing the required information below.
A Java security manager offers JVM level security beyond what is provided by the application container. It enforces access rules at the JVM runtime based on one or more security policies.

This installer will place three security policies in the installation directory with the filenames 'security.policy', 'rtgov.policy', and 'kie.policy' regardless of choice. Those policies will be enabled at runtime if the option below is selected.

Please note that a security manager imposes a significant performance overhead when enabled. It is suggested the included policies be applied in production if user requirements call for a stronger measure than what is already provided by the application container's authentication and authorization mechanism.
Please see the Data Virtualization administrative documentation for further details and consideration.
Some more explanatory text can go here as well.

The distinguished name of the context to begin searching for the user.

This contains either the LDAP attribute containing the username for the searches, or an LDAP syntax query.
The type of filter selected determines how the Username filter value is interpreted. Username attribute indicates that the supplied value is the LDAP attribute which contains the username.
A new LDAP connection requires a Connection Name, Directory Server, Distinguished Name (DN), and a confirmed DN Password. Please fill every field before proceeding.
An outbound-connection with the given name already exists. Please choose another name.
The name that this LDAP-enabled connection will be known by.
A security-realm with the given name already exists. Please choose another name.
The name that this LDAP-enabled security-realm will be known by.
Indicate whether or not the search should recurse through the LDAP directory tree.

Red Hat JBoss Enterprise Application Platform can be configured to allow you to use a LDAP server as the authentication and authorization authority, both for applications and the management interface. This is a 2-step process.
The hostname of the LDAP server to connect to.
A new LDAP security realm requires a Security Realm Name, a Base Distinguished Name (Base DN), and a Username filter. All three of these fields must be filled.

A new security realm will be added with the attributes below, and will utilize the LDAP outbound connection defined in the previous step. This new security realm will be associated with the management interfaces. The value for Filter can either be of the form attribute="value", where value is the name of the attribute which holds the username, or of the form filter="value", where value is a query in standard LDAP syntax. If using an LDAP query, escape "&" with "&"

If this computer is using a pure IPv6 configuration, please check the box below. A pure IPv6 setup requires additional configuration at runtime to ensure the proper bindings of the management and http interfaces.
Red Hat JBoss Data Virtualization quickstarts
These quickstarts will allow you to set up an already running project where you can utilize working code to build from for your projects.
Port number for @@ must be an integer within the range 1-65535.

The passwords must be at least eight characters long, with one alphabetic character, one digit, and one non-alphanumeric character, and must not match the associated username. Banned characters are &.

Define users for the EAP admininstrator, Dashboard administrator, the Teiid data access user and the ModeShape user. The password for the EAP administrator can be shared for all users as well as the default password vault.

The type of authentication cache to use with this domain. Default uses a simply Map based cache. Infinispan uses the infinispan subsystem.

The alias given to the keystore to be used in the vault.
The directory where encrypted files will be stored. This directory should be reasonably secured, but still accessible by JBoss EAP.

A new password vault requires a vault alias, a salt value, an iteration count value, a keystore password, a distinguished name, the keystore location and a directory where encrypted files will be placed. All fields are required.
The iteration count must be a positive integer.
The iteration count. This number is used with the salt value to create the hash value for the password-vault.
The keystore provided contains an unsupported key with the alias "%s". Please provide a symmetric key or create a new key by entering an unused alias.

The installer cannot generate a secret key in the provided keystore. Please enter the location of an existing JKS keystore containing a key with the provided alias, or the path to a new or existing JCEKS keystore.

The vault salt must be exactly 8 digits in length.
The salt value for the vault. This value is used with the iteration count to create the password-vault's hash value.

A password vault encrypts sensitive strings and stores them in an encrypted keystore. The vault mechanism manages decrypting the strings for use with security domains, security realms, or other verification systems.

A previously configured password vault has been detected. Please supply the password to the keystore used to create the password vault. This vault will be used to mask subsequent passwords in the installation process.
Please make note of your entry below in order to mask any subsequent passwords. See JBoss EAP 6 documentation for further details.
